reviewText: ....It's better than the first movie. But how much is that saying?. I was always a big Scooby Doo fan as a kid, and even today, I can still get into the nostalgia fun of it all if I see it on TV or wherever. I was not too interested when the original film came out a few years ago, because I couldn't see these people as live action characters. Especially when there is a talking dog involved. While the characters were decently cast(with the exception of one Mr. Prinze, Jr.), the first film was quite a dud. The location of villains were not too fun or cool, and it just wasn't good. Now, this sequel, which pretty much follows the same goofy formula of the first, is actually a lot better. Make no mistake that it is still an empty, hollow, piece of cotton candly fluff, but it is a fairly colorful, silly, and somewhat entertaining piece of cotton candy. If it weren't for my little nieces, I would never of seen this movie anyway. This time out, our fearless gang of Mystery, INC. is up against a dastardly plan that could be their biggest mission yet. A new museum is being opened in their hometown of Coolsville. A museum solely dedicated to the gang and their many exploits and mysteries over the years. Fred(Prinze, Jr.), Daphne(Sarah Michelle Gellar), Shaggy(Matthew Lillard), Velma(Linda Cardellini), and computer animated Scooby are all attending the grand opening. In the middle of the opening, the museum is attacked by the Pterodactyl(?)ghost, which is then taken by the mysterious masked man. Before long, more ghosts are popping up, and old ghosts from the gang's past(and cartoons)are being resurrected and will soon take over the town. The gang soon starts to uncover that this could possibly be the work of an old foe, or is it?. Like the cartoons, the movie has a number of red herrings. And just like the old cartoons, they are paper thin and you can see right through them. There is the museum currator Patrick(Seth Green), who is also a love interest for the lovelorn Velma. There is Heather Jasper-Howe(Alicia Silverstone), the local news reporter who is there to praise the gang, and is there to tear them down as well. Old man Wickles(Peter Boyle), is another possibility. Who is it?. Does it matter?. Do you care?. Well, not really. The cartoons, as much as I loved them, were aimed at kids, so the mysteries were never too deep or multi-layered. And sadly, neither are these live action movies. The cast does pretty well in bringing the characters to life, and managin with the silly, paper thin script by James Gunn. The best are Lillard, who is still the perfect Shaggy. He has the talk, giggle, and lanky body down to a science. The other is Cardellini as Velma. Although it's kinda hard to take since Velma is not much of a beauty, but you can see that Cardellini so obviously is. Gellar is good as Daphne, but like I said for the original review, it's disheartening to see 'Buffy' play someone so shallow and vain. But the character of Daphne always kinda was anyways. I don't see why or how Freddie got cast as Fred, or why he plays him like a 'himbo', since the cartoon Fred really wasn't. The effects are pretty decent, if not spectacular when compared to the big effects laden extravaganzas of today. But for a little kiddie movie, it does the trick well enough. But the script plays it safe. There is some flatulence laughs here, but instead of playing it to the kiddies, the writers should have taken a cue from the live action "Brady Bunch" movies and made it a more adult, tongue in cheek kind of comedy. I guess what makes this one better than the first is that it is more monster-y. It has more of that Scooby Doo vibe, with old mansions, abandoned mining towns, and more ghosts and ghouls. The original didn't really have that. All in all, it's a hollow experience that will not leave you with a more enriched life in the end. It's a harmless piece of brain dead kiddie fun that will probably please the young 'uns, and will only entertain older people who have a soft spot for the old gang at Mystery, Inc.

reviewText: The first Scooby Doo live movie was a novelty. Everyone wanted to see just how close people could come to making the characters come to life. Now the novelty has worn off and it's time for a good story. Scooby Doo 2 definitely delivers! It was absolutely awesome to see some of those famous animated baddies in "real life". This movie is far better than the first (even though Scrappy Doo doesn't make a guest appearance in this one). The mystery truly is just that--a mystery. This brings you back to the old days of the cartoon series (including a visit to the very first Mystery Inc clubhouse from the "Pup Named Scooby Doo" show), and it's a wonderfully fun ride. Daphne is no longer the damsel-in-distress, and even Fred gets a few minutes of serious action (with a Bon Jovi soundtrack, no less!). The weaknesses from the first film are virtually gone. Fred is no longer a jerk, Daphne shows a sensitive side, and Velma finally gets a love interest. Scooby and Shaggy are the focus of this film, but Matthew Lillard is able to pull off just enough of a serious edge to show us a side to Shaggy we'd missed before: a man who finally realizes that he's nothing more than a walking mistake in the cases.The special effects are great too! While some of the advertisements said that every monster they'd ever faced was coming after them, that's a little misleading. Only about 5 monsters are running loose in here, but you do get some cool cameos of costumes from other cases they've been on.All in all, this is much better than the first and definitely worth the price of admission. With or without kids, this is one movie that everyone will enjoy. Recommended.

reviewText: SCOOBY DOO 2 shows a considerable amount of improvement over the first film, but still misses the mark. After the Museum of Criminology is robbed of several costumes that were taken from the Coolsville's most notorious villains, the city's leading crime-solvers are defamed for their inability to stop the newest masked menace. Now, Scooby and the gang must set off to recover the lost artifacts if they hope to rebuild their reputations! Raja Gosnell returns to direct from another of James Gunn's scripts, this time featuring several of the most memorable villains from the original series including The Black Knight Ghost, Miner Forty-Niner, The 10,000 Volt Ghost, The Tar Monster, and The Zombie. There is a surprising shift in the acting this second round, with Freddie Prinze Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar reeling back their performances to form more likable characters as Fred and Daphne, while Linda Cardellini and Matthew Lillard fall farther from their cartoon counterparts. Apparently, technology had taken an incredible leap forward in just two short years, as the computerized villains look far better than before. Still, the messy plot and uneven humor keeps SCOOBY DOO 2 from reaching its comic potential.-Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies

reviewText: Fred, Daphne, Velma, Shaggy, and everyone's favorite crime-solving canine are back for another mystery-filled adventure, except this time around, the gang is faced with an assortment of ghoulish adversaries, who wreak havoc on both the lives of the citizens and the scenic beauty of Coolsville. But, things are not cool for our ever-popular crime-fighting tandem, who are not so popular with the public, after failing to close in on a (successful) robbery heist. To regain their glory, they must right a terrible wrong by freeing this proud community from a band of monsters who want to give Coolsville a bad name and make the city all their own. Feeling betrayed and as outcasts by the other members of their group of persistent gumshoes, Shaggy and Scooby go it alone, and want to be the first to solve the case to be in good standing with their friends. What results is a delightfully witty, charming and well-"animated" tale, including a "twofer", in that it a) has enough merit to be original on its' own, while b) containing all the frolic and "whodunnit"-worthy mayhem of the original cartoon series. Even the cute "semi-animated, semi-live" cariacature of ol' Scoob himself is the real reason of wanting to own a pet canine for yourself, what with all the tongue and outwardly physical kinetic action this version of everyone's favorite dog brings to the table (not to mention the awe-struck, muffed-up verbalization!). Even "The Mystery Machine" has never looked better, but could've been broken-in a lot more. The excellent cast (Freddie Prinze, Jr., Sarah Michelle Gellar, Matthew Lillard & Linda Cardinelli) is the glue that seamlessly holds everything together. Peter Boyle & Neil Fanning (as the voice of Scooby-Doo) are the absolute icing on the cake, with each of whom bringing their own unique artistic style to this fine production as well. "Scooby-Doo: Monsters Unleashed" adds up to clean, wholsome, good-natured family fun, at its' ultra-sheer best. A video/DVD collection wouldn't be complete without it, but don't forget to view it in all its' unhampered, animated glory at your local theater beforehand!

reviewText: The original live action SCOOBY DOO was rather like the cotton candy you buy at the fair: pretty to look at and fun to scarf down.  But a little goes a long way, particularly when all the air has been beaten out and it emerges as overworked taffy.Freddie Prinze Jr., Sarah Michelle Gellar, Matthew Lillard, and Linda Cardellini repeat the roles of Fred, Daphne, Shaggy, and Velma.  Once again, Prinze and Gellar are hardly inspired but at least they play with tremendous energy; once again Lillard and Cardellini are so dead on target that the effect is almost spooky.  They are supported by Seth Green, a truly talented actor who gives a very nice performance indeed; unfortunately, Peter Boyle is largely wasted and Alicia Silverstone is, well, Alicia Silverstone.Silverstone aside, the cast might have recreated the lightness of the first film--but once you mix in a story about stolen costumes that come to life, huge sets, wild outfits, a dance number, and a ton of CGI effects they pretty much get lost in the shuffle.  It's all about as much fun as a carnival after the crowd has gone and you're left alone with gum on the bottom of your shoe.Kids probably won't notice the shortcomings, and older fans will be glad to see numerous references to the original cartoon series--and to be fair the film does have its moments, largely thanks to Lillard, Cardellini, and Green.  But by and large this is the sort of thing you watch once and then let gather dust on the shelf.  The DVD comes with a handful of bonuses, none of them of any great interest.GFT, Amazon Reviewer
summary: More Like Overworked Taffy than Cotton Candy

reviewText: The first Scooby Doo movie was a novelty. Everyone wanted to see just how close people could come to making the characters come to life. Now the novelty has worn off and it's time for a good story. Scooby Doo 2 definitely delivers! It was great to see some of those famous animated baddies in "real life". This movie is far better than the first. In this new outing, the screenwriters have created a situation that is a classic. Scooby-Doo: Mystery, Inc.'s hometown of Coolsville is threatened by an evil masked madman who steals the costumes of the classic monsters that MI have exposed as fakes from a recent museum exhibit, and used them to create REAL versions of same.All the original cast has returned, and everyone shines in stellar performances, bringing their characters to life. Sarah Michelle Gellar and Freddie Prinze Jr. make dynamic improvements in their roles as Daphne and Fred; Gellar brings a sweetness and kindliness to Daphne that she wasn't able to with Buffy and Prinze gives Fred a sense of depth, humor and leadership. Matthew Lillard returns with another explosive performance as Shaggy, channeling this character from somewhere deep within his psyche. Lillard has developed a reputation for intense performances but with his portrayal of Shaggy, those performances are not so much eclipsed as erased. Eyes bugging, howling, screaming, limbs flailing, with the trademark cry of "[GHOST]!!!" at once terrified and RESIGNED TO the inevitable chase, Lillard nails Shaggy again and again throughout the film.The CGI Scooby, voiced deftly by Neil Fanning, seems much improved, and this time it's a proper mix of cartoon and real canine that displays the lovability and goofiness of Scooby Doo, which is much better. The supporting cast includes a sympathetic Peter Boyle as former villain Old Man Wickles, and a devious Alicia Silverstone redeems her genre-film rep from the horror that was Batman and Robin as a two-faced TV reporter who seems to be out to deface the gang's track record.All in all, this second effort is well-made and worth the time spent.  Stars all round.

reviewText: When the first Scooby-Doo came out, it was pleasant enough, but the film was hobbled under both the usual gross-out "humor" needed to attract the twentysomething crowd and the constant legends that have plagued the original series (Fred and Daphne always make out when the gang splits up, Velma's a lesbian, Scoooby and Shaggy are potheads, etc.).  In this new outing, the screenwriters eschew this nonsense for a plotline that delves into the Scooby mythos, creating a situation that is classic Scooby-Doo: Mystery, Inc.'s hometown of Coolsville is threatened by an evil masked madman who steals the costumes of the classic monsters that MI have exposed as fakes from a recent museum exhibit, and used them to create REAL versions of same.All the original cast has returned, and everyone shines in stellar performances, bringing their characters to life.  Sarah Michelle Gellar and Freddie Prinze Jr. make dynamic improvements in their roles as Daphne and Fred; Gellar brings a sweetness and kindliness to Daphne that she wasn't able to with Buffy, and Prinze gives Fred a sense of depth, humor and leadership.(...)Matthew Lillard returns with another explosive performance as Shaggy, channeling this character from somewhere deep within his psyche.  Lillard has developed a reputation for intense performances (witness 13 Ghosts or SLC Punk), but with his portrayal of Shaggy, those performances are not so much eclipsed as erased.  Eyes bugging, howling, screaming, limbs flailing, with the trademark cry of "[GHOST]!!!", at once terrified and RESIGNED TO the inevitable chase, Lillard nails Shaggy again and again throughout the film.The CGI Scooby, voiced deftly by Neil Fanning, seems much improved, and this time it's a proper mix of cartoon and real canine that displays the lovability and goofiness of Scooby Doo.  Much, much better.The supporting cast includes a sympathetic Peter Boyle as former villain Old Man Wickles, and a devious Alicia Silverstone redeems her genre-film rep from the horror that was Batman And Robin as a two-faced TV reporter who seems to be out to deface the gang's track record.  All in all, this second effort is well-made and worth the time spent.  Four stars all round.
summary: This time around, more Scooby and less Doo

reviewText: In the original "Scooby-Doo" flick, the opening scene involving the Luna ghost managed to capture the essence of the old TV series in a nutshell.  It had the "feel" of Scooby-Doo and Mystery Inc.  After that, however, the movie took a few turns away from the original show.  Not that that is a bad thing, but it felt like the film tried too hard to appease old fans, new fans, and people who actually believe that dogs talk in real life.This new film is more like the original series.  Daphne still has her kung-fu powers from the first movie, but other than that, the characters are reasonably true to form.  The monsters that are "unleashed" in this tale are actually monsters from the original series, which plugs in the nostalgia factor for us older, wiser kids.  Someone, or something, has stolen the costumes of all of Mystery, Inc.'s old foes from the Coolsville museum.  Seth Green, in a part that was perfect for him, plays the curator who falls for Velma.  He's also a prime suspect. Suspect number two is Peter Boyle, playing a whacked out criminal whose out of the pen.  There are other suspects in the flick, but I don't want to give away too much.  Alicia Silverstone plays a snoopy reporter who seems to be out to stain the good name of Mystery, Inc.  Aren't all reporters out to do that, anyway?  She does a pretty good job with her role.Although the characters are fairly accurate, the movie does have a little fun with Velma by giving her a love interest.  She goes to pretty great lengths to impress Seth Green with a little help from Daphne.  Fred deals with the fact that he isn't always the brave hero he comes across as.  Scooby and Shaggy come to realize that other than being the goof-ups, they don't add much to the Mystery, Inc. gang.  They set out to prove this wrong.Overall, a fun movie that has plenty of monsters in it to playfully scare the little ones.  There aren't any monsters or zombies of the caliber you'll find in Disney's "Haunted Mansion," so if your kids can handle that film's scares, "Scooby-Doo 2" will be a walk in the park.  If you're looking for "Star Wars" quality CGI, you'll be upset.  Most of the action looks pretty fake.  Just keep in mind that this flick has to appeal to the kids AND it's based on a cartoon with a talking dog.  As with the first film, there are plenty of fart jokes geared toward the thirteen-year old boys in the crowd.  The language isn't too saucy, though one or two middle-school words slip out.  There isn't anything too offensive here.The DVD extras are par for the course.  Like the first DVD, there is a game that includes a special prize for the winners.  Other than that, the disc is pretty standard.Recommended if you liked the first film.  This one is slightly better.  Highly recommended if you're a "Scooby" purist, since this one is a little more faithful to the show.

reviewText: I liked the cartoon show "Scooby Doo" well enough when I watched it, but I was not a devote and since it was basically the same story line each and every time I could usually find something more interested to watch.  Furthermore, I have nothing against cartoons being turned into movies.  "Josie and the Pussycats," which I admit to watching more often, made a decent enough movie.  But I have seen both of the live action "Scooby Doo" movies, including "Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed" and I am clearly at the age where I no longer even have kids young enough to enjoy these movies at the level on which they were intended.  If your age is in double-digits then you are probably too old for this movie.I know exactly what the problem is from my perspective, and it is quite simply that the lead couple of Fred (Freddie Prinze, Jr.) and Daphne (Sarah Michelle Gellar) are rather vapid imitations of their cartoon counterparts.  As a Watcher wannabe and die-hard "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" fan this critique will shock some of you, but think about it: if you took a clip from this movie of Prinze and Gellar, together or apart, and watched it without knowing who they were supposed to be, I really think it would never dawn on your that they were Fred and Daphne.  The same is certainly not true for Matthew Lillard as Shaggy, who is instantly recognizable, and Linda Cardellini is at least in the same ballpark as Velma.  I do not know if this has anything to do with Prinze and Gellar being married (I suspect not), but their characterizations are just so very, very wrong.  This is rather troubling, because how do you mess up playing a cartoon character?  At least the computer generated Scooby rings true, although, please, can we stop using flatulence as a weapon?The special effects are the best part of "Scooby-Doo 2," especially in terms of the unleashed monsters.  They were always rather simplistic (and rather two-dimensional) on the cartoon series and here they had some fun coming up with the Black Knight Ghost, Miner 49ers, and the rest of the monsters.  There is a story, in which the gang at Mystery Inc. go to opening night at a museum that exhibits the costumes of the fake monsters from all of the cases they have solved, but then one of the costumes ends u with a real monster in it and things get progressively worse.  This is especially because a local television reporter (Alicia Silverstone) is out to twist things around to make Mystery Inc. look bad.  Meanwhile there is the obligatory obvious choice for the mystery monster with Old Man Wickles (Peter Boyle) and the young curator of the museum, Patrick (Seth Green), who is interested in Velma and she is interested right back.  If you figured out who the villain was in the first film then you will probably figure it out in the second one as well, but that is never the point with Mystery Inc.This one is for kids or for those whose inner child sounds either exactly like Shaggy or exactly like Scooby.  This conclusion is reinforced by all of the DVD extras, which play to long time fans of the show much more than to causal viewer.  I suppose they will continue to make these movies as long as the cast is willing given the box office receipts to date, but the basic stories are never going to change and as much as the series would benefit from a different Fred and Daphne who were as on the mark as the other characters, I doubt that is going to happen.

reviewText: Other five star reviews have mentioned how funny the movie is, how the special effects have improved, how wonderful Matthew Lillard is, and how the movie is just plain fun--all of this is true, but for me it is more than that.Scooby Doo 2, How do I love you? Solving mysteries doesn't leave a lot of time for romance.But wait, there's some romance. And here's where the movie gets REALLY good. Congrats.On the bright side, it was nice to see some of the classic villains return, even if some of them didn't even look like they did in the cartoon, I will let it slide. One that I did like was the 10,000 Volt Ghost.  I don't think they could've made him any better.  It is really neat to see on the screen.Yet, it's not enough to save the movie. reviewText: The 2004 film "Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed" was the sequel to the 2002 "Scooby-Doo".  Based upon the "Scooby-Doo" cartoon television series that first aired in 1973, each of the live-action films attempted to recapture the original comedy and mystery of the original cartoon.  The main characters include four people and one dog that drive around in a very colorful van and happen across various mysteries, usually involving seemingly supernatural beings. They include Fred (Freddie Prinze Jr.), Daphne (Sarah Michelle Gellar), Velma (Linda Cardellini), Shaggy (Matthew Lillard) and the dog named Scooby-Doo (voice of Neil Fanning).  Of these live-action characters, the three that came closest to portraying the original animated characters are Linda Cadrelline, Matthew Lillard and Niel Fanning.This second live-action film, "Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed", begins at a museum in the fictional city of Coolsville where the five mystery solvers are being honored with an exhibition of the fanciful costumes of the various criminals that they stopped (mostly from the animated series itself).  The museum curator, Patrick (Seth Green, who also played alongside Sarah Michelle Geller in the 1997-2003 TV series "Buffy the Vampire Slayer"), has more than a professional interest in Velma; but while the party-goers at the opening of the museum collection are having a good time, suddenly, a masked madman appears and one of the costumes suddenly comes to live, seemingly on its own.  The party-goers scramble to leave, but it is only the beginning of a tirade of brought-back-to-life monsters that the Scooby-Doo and his friends had all previously defeated.Though many who have watched "Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed" were sorely disappointed with it, it's not really entirely horrible.  There are some very funny scenes and the special effects are entertaining.  Admittedly, the acting from Freddie Prinze Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar could have been better.  Other memorable characters include Old Man Wickles (Peter Boyle, who is better known for his role of Frank Barone in the 1996-2005 TV series "Everybody Loves Raymond"), Jacobo (Tim Blake Nelson) and Heather (Alicia Silverstone).  Overall, I rank the 2004 sequel "Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed" with 3 out of 5 stars.
summary: Not Great, but Not Awful Either

reviewText: This is the rare case when a sequel is better than the original. reviewText: I went to this film with my three-and-a-half-year-old because we had a free ticket.  We had not seen the original, nor had I read any reviews.  My last encounter with the goofy Scooby was in the late 1970s, when I was "that age."  That said, the characters played their parts adorably! If I had to imagine the original Scooby characters as human beings, they might well look like the Scooby-Doo 2 incarnations.  Even the van was on target!The plot was simple enough.  Mystery Inc. becomes famous, and one of the unmasked criminals attempts to destroy them.  Coolville represents a typical election year society--that loves its heroes, but quickly turns on them when times get tough (how familiar that sounds!).  Subplots develop, and we wonder who done it.  Several possiblities are there, so it is a true suspense.The whole notion:  Scooby Doo is geared towards young elementary school children, so me wonders if an animated feature might have worked better.  The romantic subplots were fun for the adults and some teens, perhaps, but do younger children really need all that?  It worked okay, but the target audience was too broad--everybody got something, but no age group got a movie that truly catered to them.Bottom-line:  This is a funny movie, and my preschooler did enjoy it.  The film doesn't take itself too seriously, and the choice to do a non-animated feature gave it broader age appeal.  However, in attempted to reach a larger audience, Scooby Doo 2 failed to be outstanding for any one age group.  A decent effort, worthy of three stars. reviewText: The first Scooby-Doo movie really wasn't any good. The plot was terrible, there were way too many occult and new age references, certain characters were totally miscast, many scenes of the movie were too frightening for young audiences, and the movie totally ruined a somewhat likeable former Mystery, Inc. member. When I had learned that they were making a sequal, I wasn't surprised but hoped that they would do a better job the second time around.Apparently the filmmakers did learn a thing or two because SCOOBY-DOO 2: MONSTERS UNLEASHED is a much better movie than the first Scooby-Doo movie. The characters get developed a little more and are more true to their original incarnations than they were in the first movie.SCOOBY-DOO 2 opens with the Mystery, Inc. gang appearing at the grand opening of a new museum in Coolsville. The museum is displaying several costumes from various mysteries the gang has solved in the past.  Most of these monsters are monsters that the Mystery, Inc. gang faced during the original Scooby-Doo series, for example the Tar Monster. Anyway, one of the monsters comes to life, makes a mess of the museum, and steals the costume of the Black Knight.  The gang investigates and soon finds that the clues they have don't seem to match up.  In the meantime, the museum is broken into again and all the costumes are stolen. From that point on it's an action-packed ride to find out who the mastermind is.SCOOBY-DOO 2 is a much better movie than the first Scooby-Doo movie.  The film feels more like the cartoons and the characters are more like the original characters than the deconstructed versions from the first movie. Matthew Lillard is once again a perfect Shaggy and Linda Cardellini brings out the sex appeal of Velma.  Sarah Michelle Gellar seems more like the Daphne from the cartoons, but still with a bit of brawn.  Unfortunately, Freddie Prinze Jr. remains totally miscast as Fred. His Fred is a little more realistic and Fredlike, but Freddie Prinze Jr. is still the wrong actor to be portraying Fred; even with the wig and makeup he doesn't even resemble Fred.Besides the complaining about miscasting Freddie Prinze Jr., there really isn't much to complain about in SCOOBY-DOO 2. The movie stays in the realm of family-friendly and has the right combination of laughs for kids and allusions for Scooby-Doo fans and other adults. The sets are a bit big and farfetched, but this is supposed to be a cartoony universe so it all seems to fit.  All the members of the gang keep their integrity and though the monsters are somewhat scary for younger children, they aren't frightening. The film is true to the spirit of the classic Scooby-Doo cartoons. If they do the same with the next picture as they did with this one, I might actually look forward to seeing SCOOBY-DOO 3.
